tit.cmt: *Unsure of the best translation for "王権". "sovereignty" is ok. I have also seen things like 'kingship' but I think in his case 'Kingdom' is sufficient

sen.j: ヤマト王権（やまとおうけん）とは、古墳時代に「大王」（おおきみ）と呼称された大王 (ヤマト王権)といくつかの有力氏族が中心となって成立した王権・政権である。
sen.e: Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereign) was a sovereign or administration that mainly consisted of a great king called okimi during the Kofun period (tumulus period) and some powerful clans.
The Yamato Kingdom is a term used to refer to the royal authority and government that developed around a monarch, known as an okimi, and several powerful clans during the Kofun period (c.250 to 538).

The Yamato Kingdom is a term used to refer to the royal authority and government that developed around a monarch, known as an okimi, and several powerful clans during the Kofun period (tumulus period).
sen.cmt: 古墳時代の時代区分は、山川出版社日本史研究P31の説明に準拠して修正しました。 (from the late third to the late seventh century)→ (tumulus period)（用語集に合わせました）

sen.j: 主に奈良盆地を本拠とした。
sen.e: The base of Yamato sovereignty was mainly in the Nara basin.
It was mainly based in the Nara basin.
It was mainly based in the Nara basin.

sen.j: かつては大和朝廷（やまとちょうてい）という呼称が用いられていた。
sen.e: In the past, the Yamato sovereignty (ヤマト王権; やまとおうけん) was called the Yamato Imperial Court (大和朝廷; やまとちょうてい).
In the past, the term Yamato Imperial Court was used.
In the past, the term Yamato Imperial Court was used.

tit.e: About the term for this sovereignty

sen.j: 1970年代より以前は大和朝廷（やまとちょうてい）と呼ばれることが多かったが、「大和」という表記は奈良時代以降のものであるとともに、この政治勢力を説明するには「朝廷」という用語は適当でないとされ、1980年代以降はヤマト王権の呼称が一般的となっている。
sen.e: Before 1970, the Yamato sovereignty (大和朝廷) was the more commonly used term to refer to this sovereignty; however, from the 1980s,"ヤマト王権" has been more common after it was pointed out that"大和" in kanji characters was used after the Nara Period and that "朝廷" (Imperial Court) was not an appropriate representation to express the political power of that time.

Until the 1970s, Yamato Imperial Court (written in Chinese characters) was the more frequently used term but, since the 1980s, Yamato Kingdom (with Yamato written phonetically) has become more common after it was pointed out that the Chinese characters for "Yamato" were not used until the Nara period and that "Imperial Court" was not an appropriate expression for the polity of that time.

Until the 1970s, Yamato Imperial Court (written in Chinese characters) was the more frequently used term but, since the 1980s, Yamato Kingdom (with Yamato written phonetically) has become more common after it was pointed out that the Chinese characters for "Yamato" were not used until the Nara period and that "Imperial Court" was not an appropriate expression for the polity of that time.

sen.j: しかし、必ずしもこの呼称が定着したわけではなく大和政権、ヤマト政権、倭国政権、倭王権などの呼称で揺れが見られる。
sen.e: However, this new term has not really been standardized; it has still been referred to in several different ways such as "大和政権","ヤマト政権","倭国政権, Wakoku seken" (Japanese Administration), and "倭王権, Waoken"(Japanese sovereignty).

However, this new term has not really become established and various other names are also used, including the Yamato Government (with "Yamato" written either in Chinese characters or phonetically), the Wa Government or the Wa Kingdom.

However, this new term has not really become established and various other names are also used, including the Yamato Government (with "Yamato" written either in Chinese characters or phonetically), the Wa Government or the Wa Kingdom.

sen.j: 学習指導要領には大和朝廷の表記が見られるが、歴史教科書の表記は前述のように様々である。
sen.e: While the government course guidelines employ the term"大和朝廷," Japanese history textbook publishers employ various different terms such as those mentioned above.
While government course guidelines employ the term Yamato Imperial Court, Japanese history textbook publishers use various different terms such as those mentioned above.
While government course guidelines employ the term Yamato Imperial Court, Japanese history textbook publishers use various different terms such as those mentioned above.

sen.j: 弥生時代においても帥升や卑弥呼などが倭国王として中国の史料に記されているように、倭国と呼ばれる政治的な結合が存在していた。
sen.e: Also in the Yayoi period, there was a political organization called Wakoku (Japan); the names of the kings of Wa, such as Suisho and Himiko (first known ruler of Japan) are found in some historical sources in China.
Already in the Yayoi period (c.300BC-c.300AD) there existed a political alliance known as Wakoku, with Chinese historical sources mentioning rulers of Wa such as King Suisho and Queen Himiko.
Already in the Yayoi period (c.300BC-c.300AD) there existed a political alliance known as Wakoku, with Chinese historical sources mentioning rulers of Wa such as King Suisho and Queen Himiko.

sen.j: その結合は必ずしも強固なものではなく、同等の力を持った政治勢力による同盟関係だったと推測されている。
sen.e: It is estimated that this political organization was not necessarily a solid one, but was established based on alliances between various political powers having equal powers.
It is believed that this political union was not necessarily a solid one, but was established based on alliances between various political powers having equal powers.
It is believed that this political union was not necessarily a solid one, but was established based on alliances between various political powers having equal powers.

sen.j: しかし、奈良盆地に日本列島における最大規模の政治拠点が構築されていたことが纏向遺跡の発掘により次第に解明されつつある。
sen.e: However after excavation discoveries of the Makimuku sites, it has gradually been found that the largest political stronghold in the Japanese archipelago was constructed in the Nara basin.
However, with excavations at the Makimuku ancient ruins, it has gradually become clear that the largest political stronghold in the Japanese archipelago was constructed in the Nara basin.
However, with excavations at the Makimuku ancient ruins, it has gradually become clear that the largest political stronghold in the Japanese archipelago was constructed in the Nara basin.

sen.j: 倭国王・卑弥呼が居住した邪馬台国の所在地をめぐっては九州説と畿内説とが並立しており結論は出ていないが、纏向遺跡は邪馬台国の有力な候補地となっている。
sen.e: There have been two theories regarding where Yamatai Koku (Yamatai Kingdom) was located: Kyoshu region and Kinai (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) region; although either of them has been proved, Makimuku sites have been thought to be the most likely remains of Yamatai Koku.

The two proposed locations for the Yamataikoku Kingdom, where Queen Himiko of Wa lived, are Kyushu and Kinai (the area around Kyoto and Nara) and although neither of them has been proved, the Makimuku ancient sites are thought to be the most likely remains of Yamataikoku.

The two proposed locations for the Yamataikoku Kingdom, where Queen Himiko of Wa lived, are Kyushu and Kinai (the area around Kyoto and Nara) and although neither of them has been proved, the Makimuku ancient sites are thought to be the most likely remains of Yamataikoku.

sen.j: 纏向遺跡が中国史書における邪馬台国であったかどうかは議論の余地がある。
sen.e: It is still uncertain if the Makimuku sites correspond to Yamatai Koku.
It is still uncertain if the Makimuku sites correspond to the Yamataikoku mentioned in Chinese sources.
It is still uncertain if the Makimuku sites correspond to the Yamataikoku mentioned in Chinese sources.

sen.j: しかし、纏向遺跡に搬入された土器特徴から、考古学的にはおそくとも弥生時代末期までには、纏向遺跡の地を支配する勢力を中心に東海地方から北陸・近畿・阿讃瀬戸内・吉備・出雲ならびに北部九州までの各地の政治勢力がなんらかの形で参加したヤマト王権の原型ともいえる緩やかな政治連合が形成されていたことになる。
sen.e: However, from the features observed from the earthware of the Makimuku sites, it is estimated that at least by the end of the Yayoi Period, local political powers existed from the Tokai region to Hokuriku, Kinki, Asan Setouchi, Kibi, Izumo and the North of Kyushu participated in the central political power located in the Makimuku sites and formed a mild political alliance that is thought to have been the foundation of the Yamato sovereignty.

However, from features observed in pottery from the Makimuku sites, it is believed that by the end of the Yayoi Period at the latest, regional political powers from the Tokai region down through Hokuriku, Kinki, Asan Setouchi, Kibi, Izumo to northern Kyushu participated in the central polity located in the Makimuku sites, forming a loose political alliance that is thought to have been the foundation of the Yamato Kingdom.

However, from features observed in pottery from the Makimuku sites, it is believed that by the end of the Yayoi Period at the latest, regional political powers from the Tokai region down through Hokuriku, Kinki, Asan Setouchi, Kibi, Izumo to northern Kyushu participated in the central polity located in the Makimuku sites, forming a loose political alliance that is thought to have been the foundation of the Yamato Kingdom.

sen.j: また最近では特に弥生時代末期における特に出雲勢力の鉄の普及によりヤマト王権が勃興したことが考古学的に明らかにされている。
sen.e: Furthermore, archaeological studies prove that the spread of iron from the Izumo region during the end of Yayoi Period was the major cause that brought prosperity to the Yamato sovereignty.
Furthermore, archaeological studies have proved that the spread of iron from the Izumo region towards the end of the Yayoi Period was the major reason for the Yamato Kingdom's sudden prosperity.
Furthermore, archaeological studies have proved that the spread of iron from the Izumo region towards the end of the Yayoi Period was the major reason for the Yamato Kingdom's sudden prosperity.

sen.j: 対して、古墳時代に入ると規格化された前方後円墳が奈良盆地に発生し、急速に九州から東北まで普及していることから各地の政治勢力に一定の支配力を及ぼしうる政治権力が奈良盆地に成立したと考えられている。
sen.e: However, as it has been found that standardized keyhole-shaped mounds began to appear in the Nara basin and spread to Kyushu and Tohoku in the Kofun period, it is thought that the political power that had influence over those of other areas was established in the Nara basin in the Kofun period.

However, as it has been found that standardized keyhole-shaped mounds first appeared during the Kofun period in the Nara basin and then spread to Kyushu and Tohoku, it is thought that the political power that had influence over those of other areas was established in the Nara basin.

However, as it has been found that standardized keyhole-shaped mounds first appeared during the Kofun period in the Nara basin and then spread to Kyushu and Tohoku, it is thought that the political power that had influence over those of other areas was established in the Nara basin.

sen.j: 前方後円墳には畿内から吉備国（山陽地方）、筑紫国（北部九州）など各地の墓制（→弥生時代の墓制）が採り入れられているため、これらの地域勢力が連合し統一的な政治勢力となったことの反映だとされている。
sen.e: The styles of tombing from different regions, such as Kinai, Kibi County (Sanyo region) and Chikushi County (Northern Kyoshu), are observed in the keyhole-shaped mounds; it is thought that they represent the influential local political powers during the process of forming the unified political power.

The fact that keyhole-shaped mounds combine tomb styles from different regions, such as Kinai, Kibi Province (Sanyo region) and Chikushi Province (Northern Kyushu), is believed to be evidence that these regional powers formed an alliance and became one unified power.

The fact that keyhole-shaped mounds combine tomb styles from different regions, such as Kinai, Kibi Province (Sanyo region) and Chikushi Province (Northern Kyushu), is believed to be evidence that these regional powers formed an alliance and became one unified power.

sen.j: 最初の前方後円墳は3世紀前葉～中葉に出現しているのでヤマト王権の成立をこの時期に求める説が有力だが、この時期はまだヤマト王権に先立つ王権の段階（プレ・ヤマト王権）だったとする見解もある。
sen.e: As the first keyhole-shaped mounds appeared between the beginning and middle of the third century, the most widely believed theory claims that the Yamato sovereignty was established around this time; however, some theories view that there was a different sovereignty governing and that the Yamato sovereignty emerged after this.

As the first keyhole-shaped mounds appeared between the beginning and middle of the third century, the most widely believed theory claims that the Yamato Kingdom was established around this time; however, there is also a theory that this was a different kingdom (the pre-Yamato Kingdom) and that the Yamato Kingdom emerged after this.

As the first keyhole-shaped mounds appeared between the beginning and middle of the third century, the most widely believed theory claims that the Yamato Kingdom was established around this time; however, there is also a theory that this was a different kingdom (the pre-Yamato Kingdom) and that the Yamato Kingdom emerged after this.

sen.j: 各地域の勢力が連合してヤマト王権となっていく過程はまだ解明されていない。
sen.e: The process of how each local political power unified and changed into the Yamato sovereignty is still unknown.
The process of how the regional political powers unified and changed into the Yamato Kingdom is still unknown.
The process of how the regional political powers unified and changed into the Yamato Kingdom is still unknown.

sen.j: 弥生時代後期に倭国王だった卑弥呼を中心とする政治勢力（邪馬台国）が各地の勢力を服属させ、もしくは各地の勢力と連合してヤマト王権を築いたとする説のほか、邪馬台国を滅ぼした別の勢力がヤマト王権となったとする説などがある。
sen.e: Some theories claim that the political power led by Himiko (the Yamatai Koku) put other local political powers under their control or allied with them and established the Yamato sovereignty; others believe that a different political power that destroyed the Yamatai Koku established the Yamato sovereignty.

Some theories claim that the political power led by Himiko (Yamataikoku) either brought other regional powers under its control or allied with them and established the Yamato Kingdom; others believe that a different political power destroyed Yamataikoku and established the Yamato Kingdom.

Some theories claim that the political power led by Himiko (Yamataikoku) either brought other regional powers under its control or allied with them and established the Yamato Kingdom; others believe that a different political power destroyed Yamataikoku and established the Yamato Kingdom.

sen.j: 遅くとも3世紀中ばまでにヤマト・吉備・筑紫などの諸勢力が糾合し、初期ヤマト王権が形成されたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is thought that some political powers, such as Yamato, Kibi and Chikushi, rallied and formed the Yamato sovereignty at least by the third century.
It is thought that some political powers, such as Yamato, Kibi and Chikushi, had grouped together and formed the Yamato Kingdom by the third century at the latest.
It is thought that some political powers, such as Yamato, Kibi and Chikushi, had grouped together and formed the Yamato Kingdom by the third century at the latest.

sen.j: ヤマト王権の王統についても複数説が提出されている。
sen.e: There have been various theories as to the royal line of the Yamato sovereignty.
There have been various theories as to the royal line of the Yamato Kingdom.
There have been various theories as to the royal line of the Yamato Kingdom.

sen.j: 卑弥呼-台与の王統を継承しているとする説、壱与で王統が断絶し新たな王統が発生したとする説、初期ヤマト王権の王位は世襲ではなく有力豪族間で継承されたとする説、初期の王統は途中で断絶して4世紀前期ごろにミマキイリヒコ（崇神天皇）が新たな王統を開始したとする説などがある。
sen.e: Different theories that currently exist hold the following views on the royal lines of the Yamato sovereignty: originated from Himiko and Toyo; when the first royal line ended after Iyo a new one appeared; the royal line during the beginning of Yamato sovereignty was not heredity but was succeeded between different Gozoku (local ruling families); the first royal line ended somewhere and Imakiirihiko (Emperor Sujin) started a new royal line around the beginning of the fourth century.

Theories about the royal lines of the Yamato Kingdom include that it originated from Himiko and Toyo; that the first royal line ended with Iyo and a new one appeared; that the royal line during the beginning of the Yamato Kingdom was not heredity but was shared between different powerful families; that the first royal line died out and Imakiirihiko (Emperor Sujin) started a new one around the beginning of the fourth century.
sen.cmt: *I believe 台与 and 壱与 were the same person but since the original uses different kanji, I left the different English versions
sen.e: Theories about the royal lines of the Yamato Kingdom include that it originated from Himiko and Toyo; that the first royal line ended with Iyo and a new one appeared; that the royal line during the beginning of the Yamato Kingdom was not heredity but was shared between different powerful families; that the first royal line died out and Mimakiirihiko (Emperor Sujin) started a new one around the beginning of the fourth century.

sen.j: 前方後円墳の分布は4世紀後葉前まで、主に畿内～瀬戸内海沿岸（吉備国など）～北九州（筑紫国など）に集中していた。
sen.e: Before the latter half of the fourth century, keyhole-shaped mounds were mainly seen around the regions ranging from the Kinai to the coast of Seto Inland Sea (such as Kibi County) and northern Kyushu (such as Chikushi County).
Before the latter half of the fourth century, keyhole-shaped mounds were mainly seen in the Kinai, Seto Inland Sea (such as Kibi County) and northern Kyushu (such as Chikushi County) regions.
Before the latter half of the fourth century, keyhole-shaped mounds were mainly seen in the Kinai, Seto Inland Sea (such as Kibi County) and northern Kyushu (such as Chikushi County) regions.

sen.j: そのため、ヤマト王権の支配権もそれらの地域を中心としていたと考えられる。
sen.e: It is thought that the hegemony of the Yamato sovereignty was also exerted mainly in these regions.
It is thought that the Yamato Kingdom also exerted its hegemony mainly in these regions.
It is thought that the Yamato Kingdom also exerted its hegemony mainly in these regions.

sen.j: しかし4世紀後葉になると、東北（仙台平野・会津地方など）から南九州（日向・大隅など）まで前方後円墳の分布が急速に拡大しており、ヤマト王権の支配権がそれらの地域へ伸展していったことの表れだとする見方がある。
sen.e: However, it has been discovered that there was a rapid spread of keyhole-shaped mounds to other regions such as from Tohoku (Sendai plain and Aizu Region) to the South of Kyoshu during the latter half of the fourth century; therefore, some view this fact affirms the extension of Yamato sovereignty's hegemony in other areas.

However, during the latter half of the fourth century, keyhole-shaped mounds spread rapidly from Tohoku (Sendai plain and Aizu Region) to southern Kyushu, which is seen as evidence of the Yamato Kingdom extending its hegemony in other areas.

However, during the latter half of the fourth century, keyhole-shaped mounds spread rapidly from Tohoku (Sendai plain and Aizu Region) to southern Kyushu, which is seen as evidence of the Yamato Kingdom extending its hegemony in other areas.

sen.j: この時期と前後して4世紀半ば（350年頃）からヤマト王権（倭国）は朝鮮半島との交易を開始した。
sen.e: Around this time, in the middle of the fourth century (around 350), the Yamato sovereignty (Wakoku) began trading with the Korean Peninsula.
Around this time, in the middle of the fourth century (around 350), the Yamato Kingdom (Wakoku) began trading with the Korean Peninsula.
Around this time, in the middle of the fourth century (around 350), the Yamato Kingdom (Wakoku) began trading with the Korean Peninsula.

sen.j: 当時の倭国には鉄鉱の産出がなく、朝鮮半島から鉄原料を輸入した。
sen.e: Because iron ore was not produced in Wakoku around that time, raw material of iron was imported from the Korean Peninsula.
Because iron ore was not produced in Wakoku at that time, iron was imported from the Korean Peninsula.
Because iron ore was not produced in Wakoku at that time, iron was imported from the Korean Peninsula.

sen.j: 朝鮮半島の任那（伽耶）は鉄の産地だった。
sen.e: Mimana (Gaya) was a production area of iron.
Gaya (known as Minama in Japanese) was one area that produced iron.
Gaya (known as Minama in Japanese) was one area that produced iron.

sen.j: 輸入した鉄資源をもとに鍬・鋤などの農業用鉄製品が製造され、農業技術の革新・開墾の活発化などが起こり4世紀後葉から5世紀にかけて倭国の農業生産力は大きく向上した。
sen.e: As iron products for agricultural uses, such as hoes or harrows, were manufactured by this import, it brought about a revolution in agricultural technology and active cultivation of the farmlands that led to the rapid growth of agricultural production of Wakoku around the end of fourth and fifth century.

The imported iron was used to make agricultural implements such as hoes and harrows, bringing about a revolution in agricultural technology and increasing land cultivation, which led to a rapid increase in Wakoku's agricultural production capabilities around the end of fourth to the fifth century.

The imported iron was used to make agricultural implements such as hoes and harrows, bringing about a revolution in agricultural technology and increasing land cultivation, which led to a rapid increase in Wakoku's agricultural production capabilities around the end of fourth to the fifth century.

sen.j: これにより、経済力をつけたヤマト王権は鉄資源を求めて朝鮮半島へ経済的・軍事的に進出し始めた。
sen.e: Due to these societal changes, the Yamato sovereignty gained more economical power and began economic and military invasions of the Korean Peninsula in search of iron.
Due to these societal changes, the Yamato Kingdom became economically stronger and began economic and military invasions of the Korean Peninsula in search of iron.
Due to these societal changes, the Yamato Kingdom became economically stronger and began economic and military invasions of the Korean Peninsula in search of iron.

sen.j: ヤマト王権（倭国）は百済と連携して朝鮮半島南部への出兵を頻繁に展開し、このことは高句麗が遺した広開土王碑にも記述されている。
sen.e: The Yamato sovereignty (Wakoku) began dispatching troops to the south of the Korea Peninsula in collaboration with Kudara (Baekje, Paekche); this has been recorded in the Gwanggaeto Stele built by Goguryeo (the kingdom of Korea).

The Gwanggaeto Stele, erected by the Korean Kingdom of Goguryeo, states that the Yamato Kingdom (Wakoku) began dispatching troops to the southern Korean Peninsula in collaboration with the Kingdom of Baekje.

The Gwanggaeto Stele, erected by the Korean Kingdom of Goguryeo, states that the Yamato Kingdom (Wakoku) began dispatching troops to the southern Korean Peninsula in collaboration with the Kingdom of Baekje.

sen.j: また、朝鮮半島南部を中心にいくつもの倭独特の前方後円墳が発見されており、中国の史書からも倭への朝鮮半島南部の支配権を認める記述があることから朝鮮半島南部（任那）は大和王権が統治していた地と有力視されている。
sen.e: Furthermore, it is strongly believed that the south of the Korean Peninsula (Mimana) was governed by the Yamato sovereignty from the fact that some features unique to Wakoku are observed in some keyhole-shaped mounds that have been discovered there and from the records of the Chinese history books that described Wakoku's monarchy over the south of the Korean Peninsula.

Furthermore, from the discovery of keyhole-shaped mounds, a feature unique to Wakoku, together with descriptions in Chinese historical sources of Wa controlling the southern Korean Peninsula, it is regarded that the Yamato Kingdom governed southern Korea.

Furthermore, from the discovery of keyhole-shaped mounds, a feature unique to Wakoku, together with descriptions in Chinese historical sources of Wa controlling the southern Korean Peninsula, it is regarded that the Yamato Kingdom governed southern Korea.

sen.j: ヤマト王権と朝鮮半島諸国との交易が活発化した背景には、北方の高句麗から圧迫を受けつつあった百済が対抗のために近隣諸国（新羅・加羅諸国）と連携を強めていたことが挙げられる。
sen.e: It is thought that Wakoku's trading with various countries in the Korean Peninsula became more active as Kudara (Baekje, Paekche) began strengthening the alliances with the neighbouring countries such as Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) and Kaya.

It is thought that trade between Wakoku and the Korean kingdoms increased as Baekje, under pressure from Goguryeo to the north, began strengthening alliances with neighboring kingdoms such as Silla and Gaya.

It is thought that trade between Wakoku and the Korean kingdoms increased as Baekje, under pressure from Goguryeo to the north, began strengthening alliances with neighboring kingdoms such as Silla and Gaya.

sen.j: この結果、ヤマト王権（倭国）と朝鮮半島諸国との関係・通交が活発化したのである。
sen.e: This led the Yamato sovereignty (Wakoku) to actively interact with various countries in the Korean Peninsula.
This led to increased interaction between the Yamato Kingdom (Wakoku) and the Korean kingdoms.
This led to increased interaction between the Yamato Kingdom (Wakoku) and the Korean kingdoms.

sen.j: ヤマト王権が東北から南九州まで全国的に展開したことは、この朝鮮半島諸国との活発な関係・通交が密接に関係していると考えられている。
sen.e: It is thought that the development of the Yamato sovereignty from Tohoku to Kyushu is strongly connected to Yamato sovereignty's active interaction with those countries in the Korean Peninsula.
It is thought that the Yamato Kingdom's development nationwide, from Tohoku to southern Kyushu, was strongly connected to its interaction with the Korean kingdoms.
It is thought that the Yamato Kingdom's development nationwide, from Tohoku to southern Kyushu, was strongly connected to its interaction with the Korean kingdoms.

sen.j: 4世紀後葉より以前ヤマトの王の墓はヤマト（奈良盆地）に営まれていたが、それ以降は河内平野に築かれることが多くなった。
sen.e: Before the latter half of the fourth century, king tombs of the Yamato sovereignty were placed in the Yamato (Nara basin), however, more were built in the Kawachi Plain after this time.
Until the latter half of the fourth century, the Yamato Kingdom's royal tombs were situated in Yamato (the Nara Basin), but after that, the majority were built in the Kawachi Plain.
Until the latter half of the fourth century, the Yamato Kingdom's royal tombs were situated in Yamato (the Nara Basin), but after that, the majority were built in the Kawachi Plain.

sen.j: このことから王権の基盤がヤマトから河内国へ移動したとする説、王権の基盤はヤマトだが海外通交の窓口となる河内を開発したとする説、それまでの王統が断絶して新王統が成立したとする説（王朝交替説）、などが提出されている。
sen.e: To explain this, various theories have developed such as: the foundation of the sovereignty moved from Yamato to the Kawachi Plain;, the foundation still remained in Yamato, but the Kawachi Plain was developed as the port to trade with foreign countries; the first royal line ended and a new one was established (change of sovereignties).

Theories to explain this include the Kingdom's base moving from Yamato to the Kawachi Plain; the base remaining in Yamato, but the Kawachi Plain being developed as a port to trade with foreign countries; or the original royal line ending and a new one being established (the Dynastic Change Theory).

Theories to explain this include the Kingdom's base moving from Yamato to the Kawachi Plain; the base remaining in Yamato, but the Kawachi Plain being developed as a port to trade with foreign countries; or the original royal line ending and a new one being established (the Dynastic Change Theory).

sen.j: 日本書紀の記述などから少なくともオオササギ王（仁徳天皇）は大阪に本拠を置き河内平野を開発したことが判っており、当時の河川改修痕跡（難波の堀江）や堤防痕跡（茨田堤）も残存している。
sen.e: From the records of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), it has been uncovered that at least King Osasagi (Emperor Nintoku) set his base in Osaka and developed the Kawachi Plain; evidences of river improvement (Horie in Namba) and bank (Mamuta-no-tsutsumi, Manda Levee) still remain present.

From descriptions in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), it has become clear that at least one ruler, King Osasagi (Emperor Nintoku), made his base in Osaka and developed the Kawachi Plain; evidence of river improvement (the Naniwa-horie canal) and embankments (Manda-no-tsutsumi levee) can still be seen today.

From descriptions in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), it has become clear that at least one ruler, King Osasagi (Emperor Nintoku), made his base in Osaka and developed the Kawachi Plain; evidence of river improvement (the Naniwa-horie canal) and embankments (Manda-no-tsutsumi levee) can still be seen today.

sen.j: 5世紀に入ると、ヤマト王権の王は中国王朝へ朝貢を始めた。
sen.e: In the fifth century, the Yamato sovereignty began paying tributes to the Chinese dynasty.
In the fifth century, the Yamato Kingdom began paying tributes to the Chinese Court.
In the fifth century, the Yamato Kingdom began paying tributes to the Chinese Court.

sen.j: 修貢して倭国王に冊封された王が中国史書に5名記されていることから、これらの王は倭の五王と呼ばれる。
sen.e: According to a Chinese history book, five figures from Wakoku paid tributes to the Chinese dynasty and were conferred peerage as the kings of Wakoku; they are called the five kings of Wa.
According to Chinese historical sources, five figures from Wakoku paid tributes to the Chinese Court and were recognized as the kings of Wakoku; they are called the Five Kings of Wa.
According to Chinese historical sources, five figures from Wakoku paid tributes to the Chinese Court and were recognized as the kings of Wakoku; they are called the Five Kings of Wa.

sen.j: 朝貢を行った理由・背景は明確にはなっていないが、おそらく朝鮮半島南部諸国（任那・伽耶）に於ける利権争いへの参入を有利に進めるためであろうと考えられており、実際に中国史書には倭へ朝鮮半島南部の支配権を認める内容を記している。
sen.e: Although the reason and the background of tributes by the Wakoku have not been clear yet, it is thought that it was for the purpose of carrying out the participation plan of the competition over interests and rights in the countries in the south of the Korean Peninsula (Mimana and Kaya) to its favour; as the matter of fact, a Chinese history book mentions the Wakoku's hegemony over the south of the Korean Peninsula.

Although the reasons for and the background to these tributes by Wakoku remain unclear, it is thought they may have been to provide an advantage in the competition over interests and rights in the kingdoms of the southern Korean Peninsula (the Gaya Confederacy) and in fact, Chinese sources mention Wakoku's hegemony over the southern Korean Peninsula.

Although the reasons for and the background to these tributes by Wakoku remain unclear, it is thought they may have been to provide an advantage in the competition over interests and rights in the kingdoms of the southern Korean Peninsula (the Gaya Confederacy) and in fact, Chinese sources mention Wakoku's hegemony over the southern Korean Peninsula.

sen.j: 中国や朝鮮半島諸国との通交・人的交流などにより技術や文化を持った多くの人々が渡来し、ヤマト（倭国）へ貢献した。
sen.e: Many people who were engaged in technology or cultural activities landed from China and Korean Peninsula to Japan through trades and interactions and contributed to the development of Yamato (Wakoku).
Many people who were engaged in technology or cultural activities came over from China and the Korean Peninsula through trade and interaction, contributing to the development of Yamato (Wakoku).
Many people who were engaged in technology or cultural activities came over from China and the Korean Peninsula through trade and interaction, contributing to the development of Yamato (Wakoku).

sen.j: 渡来人（帰化人）は養蚕、機織り、陶磁器、建築などの先進技術や『論語』に代表される中国文化、文筆・出納などの実務技術をヤマト（倭国）へもたらした。
sen.e: The settlers (naturalized citizens) brought advanced technologies such as sericulture, weaving, earthware, and architecture, Chinese culture such as "Rongo (Analects of Confucius)," practical skills such as literary art and receipts and expenditure (disbursements) to Yamato (Wakoku).

These 'toraijin' (naturalized citizens) brought advanced technologies such as sericulture, weaving, ceramics, and architecture, as well as Chinese culture from the "Analects of Confucius," practical skills such as writing and accounting to Yamato (Wakoku).

These 'toraijin' (naturalized citizens) brought advanced technologies such as sericulture, weaving, ceramics, and architecture, as well as Chinese culture from the "Analects of Confucius," practical skills such as writing and accounting to Yamato (Wakoku).

sen.j: ヤマト王権はこれらの渡来人や全国各地の豪族たちを徐々に組織化していくとともに（部民制の形成）中央の豪族層を大臣 (日本)・連を頂点として系列化していった。
sen.e: The Yamato sovereignty gradually began organizing these settlers and local ruling families (the formation of bemin sei, the system of Yamato Dynasty) and aligning central local ruling families in the top positions such as oomi and muraji, the titles given to the officers in the highest positions during the Yamato Dynasty.
The Yamato Kingdom gradually organized these settlers and the regional ruling elite (the formation of the bemin system) and placed the central ruling families in the top oomi and muraji positions.
The Yamato Kingdom gradually organized these settlers and the regional ruling elite (the formation of the bemin system) and placed the central ruling families in the top oomi and muraji positions.

sen.j: これにより、5世紀ごろには簡易な官僚制が形成されていたとして、それまでの王の権威を権力の源泉としていた「ヤマト王権」から王を中心とする政治組織が権力を担う「ヤマト政権」への転換がなされたとする見方もある。
sen.e: As seen from these organizational changes, it is thought that a simple bureaucracy system was already being formed around the fifth century; some view that during this time, the Yamato sovereignty was replaced with the Yamato regime where the authority shifted from the king to the political organization of king in the central position.

As seen from these organizational changes, it is thought that a simple bureaucratic system was already being formed around the fifth century; there is an opinion that during this time, the "Yamato Kingdom", where the king's authority was the source of power, was replaced by the "Yamato administration", where a political organization, with a King at the center, held the power.

As seen from these organizational changes, it is thought that a simple bureaucratic system was already being formed around the fifth century; there is an opinion that during this time, the "Yamato Kingdom", where the king's authority was the source of power, was replaced by the "Yamato administration", where a political organization, with a King at the center, held the power.

sen.j: この期間のヤマト王権（ヤマト政権）を代表するのがワカタケル王（雄略天皇）である。
sen.e: The representative figure of the Yamato sovereignty (Yamato regime) during this time was the King Wakatakeru (Emperor Yuryaku).
The main figure of the Yamato Kingdom (Yamato administration) during this time was King Wakatakeru (Emperor Yuryaku).
The main figure of the Yamato Kingdom (Yamato administration) during this time was King Wakatakeru (Emperor Yuryaku).

sen.j: ワカタケル王に比定される倭王武が中国へ送った上表文にはヤマト王権が各地を征服していった様が記述されているが、考古史料からは倭国内部に独自性を持った首長層が多数存在していたことが示唆されている。
sen.e: There is a description in the Johyobun (memorial to the Emperor) that shows the process of the Yamato sovereignty conquering various regions sent by Waobu (the last king of ancient Japan), a figure identified as the King Wakatakeru: also, some archaeological materials suggest that many groups of shucho (head of organization, organisation) having their own unique features existed within Wakoku.

A description in the Johyobun (Memorial to the Emperor), sent to China by Waobu, a figure identified as the King Wakatakeru, shows that the Yamato Kingdom appeared to conquer various regions, although some historical materials suggest that many chiefs maintained their autonomy.

A description in the Johyobun (Memorial to the Emperor), sent to China by Waobu, a figure identified as the King Wakatakeru, shows that the Yamato Kingdom appeared to conquer various regions, although some historical materials suggest that many chiefs maintained their autonomy.

sen.j: このことから、当時の実態はヤマト王権が他の首長より優越はしているが強い支配関係にはなく、ヤマトと他地域の連合政権的な性格だったと考えられている。
sen.e: From these records, it is thought that the Yamato sovereignty was in a superior position to other shucho of other political organizations, however, they were not in a firm dominance relationship, but the relationship seen in the coalition government.
From these records, it is thought that although the Yamato Kingdom was superior to other chiefs, it was not a strongly dominant relationship, but rather more like a coalition government.
From these records, it is thought that although the Yamato Kingdom was superior to other chiefs, it was not a strongly dominant relationship, but rather more like a coalition government.

sen.j: 日本書紀の記述から、5世紀後半には吉備や播磨、伊勢などの首長がヤマト王権へ対抗するなどの動きがあったと推測されており、そうした中で登場したワカタケル王は強化した軍事力をもとに各地の首長への支配力を強めていった。
sen.e: From the descriptions of the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), it is estimated that the shucho of Kibi, Harima, and Ise rebelled against the Yamato sovereignty around the latter half of the fifth century; King Wakatakeru appeared during this time and strengthened the political power of the Yamato sovereignty over each local chiefs with their enforced military force.

From descriptions in the "Nihonshoki", it is believed that the chiefs of Kibi, Harima, and Ise rebelled against the Yamato Kingdom sometime around the latter half of the fifth century and it was during this period that King Wakatakeru appeared and strengthened the political power of the Yamato Kingdom over the regional chiefs with its increased military strength.

From descriptions in the "Nihonshoki", it is believed that the chiefs of Kibi, Harima, and Ise rebelled against the Yamato Kingdom sometime around the latter half of the fifth century and it was during this period that King Wakatakeru appeared and strengthened the political power of the Yamato Kingdom over the regional chiefs with its increased military strength.

sen.j: そうしたワカタケル王の努力に関わらず5世紀後半から6世紀前半にかけて王統が弱体化し、数回断絶したとの説も有力である。
sen.e: In spite of King Wakatakeru's efforts, the royal line weakened during the late fifth century and the beginning of the sixth century; some theories that claim that the line ended several times are widely accepted.

In spite of King Wakatakeru's efforts, the royal line weakened between the late fifth century and the beginning of the sixth century; some widely accepted theories claim that the line ended several times.

In spite of King Wakatakeru's efforts, the royal line weakened between the late fifth century and the beginning of the sixth century; some widely accepted theories claim that the line ended several times.

sen.j: 中国王朝との通交も途絶した。
sen.e: During this time, trading with Chinese dynasty also stopped.
During this time, trade with the Chinese Court also stopped.
During this time, trade with the Chinese Court also stopped.

sen.j: 5世紀後半の475年、高句麗の南下によって百済は南方へ移動したが、この事件は百済と友好関係にあったヤマト王権（倭国）にも経済的・政治的な影響を与えた。
sen.e: During the late fifth century, in 475, Kudara (Baekje, Paekche) moved further south as Goguryeo (kingdom of Korea) advanced southward; economically and politically, this move also influenced the Yamato sovereignty (Wakoku) that had the harmonious relationship with Kudara (Baekje, Paekche).

During the late fifth century, in 475, Baekje moved further south as Goguryeo advanced southward, and this economically and politically affected the Yamato Kingdom, was had a friendly relationship with Baekje.

During the late fifth century, in 475, Baekje moved further south as Goguryeo advanced southward, and this economically and politically affected the Yamato Kingdom, that had a friendly relationship with Baekje.

sen.j: ヤマト王権は百済との友好関係を基盤として朝鮮半島南部に経済基盤・政治基盤を築いていたが、半島における百済勢力の後退によりヤマト王権が保持していた半島南部の基盤が弱体化し、このことが鉄資源の輸入減少をもたらした。
sen.e: The Yamato sovereignty maintained economical and political foundation in the south of Korean Peninsula owing to their harmonious relationship they had with Kudara (Baekje, Paekche), however, as the power of Kudara (Baekje, Paekche) diminished, the foundation established in the south o Korean Peninsula weakened, and this led the amount of iron import decline.

The Yamato Kingdom maintained an economic and political base in southern Korea owing to their friendly relationship with Baekje, but as Baekje's power diminished, this base weakened, leading to a decline in iron imports.

The Yamato Kingdom maintained an economic and political base in southern Korea owing to their friendly relationship with Baekje, but as Baekje's power diminished, this base weakened, leading to a decline in iron imports.

sen.j: そのためヤマト（倭国）内の農業開発が停滞し、ヤマト王権とその傘下の豪族達の経済力・政治力が後退したと考えられており、6世紀前半までのヤマト王統の混乱はこの経済力・政治力の後退に起因するとされる。
sen.e: For the reasons in above, it is thought that the agricultural development in Yamato (Wakoku) remained stagnant and the Yamato sovereignty and Gozoku (local ruling families) under their jurisdiction weakened; it is viewed that this confusion existed until the beginning of the sixth century was due this economical and political break down.

For this reason, it is thought that agricultural development in Yamato (Wakoku) remained stagnant, weakening the Yamato Kingdom and the ruling elite under their jurisdiction, a situation that existed until the beginning of the sixth century.

For this reason, it is thought that agricultural development in Yamato (Wakoku) remained stagnant, weakening the Yamato Kingdom and the ruling elite under their jurisdiction, a situation that existed until the beginning of the sixth century.

sen.j: また5世紀末から6世紀初めにかけて、それまで首長墓を造営してきた古墳群の多くが衰退し、新興の古墳群が出現していることから、ワカタケル大王の王権強化策は成功したが、その一方で旧来の勢力からの反発を招き、その結果として王権が一時的に弱体化したとの説もある。
sen.e: Furthermore, as many of the burial mounds that erected the tombs of shucho began to diminish and new types of burial mounds emerged instead from the end of the fifth century and the sixth century; it is thought that King Wakatakeru's strategy for strengthening sovereignty succeeded, but their power temporarily weakened due to the rebellions from the former political powers.

Furthermore, since towards the end of the fifth and the beginning of the sixth centuries many of the old burial mounds where chiefs were entombed went into decline and new types of burial mounds emerged, it is thought that King Wakatakeru's strategy for strengthening sovereignty succeeded, although his power was temporarily weakened by rebellions from the former powers.

Furthermore, since towards the end of the fifth and the beginning of the sixth centuries many of the old burial mounds where chiefs were entombed went into decline and new types of burial mounds emerged, it is thought that King Wakatakeru's strategy for strengthening sovereignty succeeded, although his power was temporarily weakened by rebellions from the former powers.

sen.j: そうした中で6世紀前期に近江国から北陸地方にかけての首長層を背景としたオホド王（継体天皇）が現れヤマト王統を統一した。
sen.e: During this time, King Ohodo (Emperor Keitai) appeared among the shucho from each group of the regions between the Omi Province and Hokuriku region in the sixth century and unified the Yamato sovereignty.
During the early sixth century, King Ohodo (Emperor Keitai) appeared from among the chiefs of regions between Omi Province and the Hokuriku region and unified the Yamato royalty.
During the early sixth century, King Ohodo (Emperor Keitai) appeared from among the chiefs of regions between Omi Province and the Hokuriku region and unified the Yamato royalty.

sen.j: オホド王の治世には北九州の有力豪族である筑紫君磐井が新羅と連携してヤマト王権との軍事衝突を起こした（磐井の乱）がすぐに鎮圧された。
sen.e: During the time of King Ohodo, Tsukushinokimiiwai, a powerful gozoku in the north Kyoshu, allied with Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) and had a military conflict (Iwai War) with the Yamato sovereignty, however, it was immediately suppressed.

During King Ohodo's reign, the Tsukushinokimiiwai, a powerful family from northern Kyushu, allied with the Korean kingdom of Silla and started hostilities (the Iwai War) with the Yamato Kingdom, though these were immediately suppressed.

During King Ohodo's reign, the Tsukushinokimi-Iwai, a powerful family from northern Kyushu, allied with the Korean kingdom of Silla and started hostilities (the Iwai War) with the Yamato Kingdom, though these were immediately suppressed.

sen.j: しかし、この事件を契機としてヤマト王権による朝鮮半島南部への進出活動が急速に衰えることとなった。
sen.e: However, due to this incident, the Yamato sovereignty rapidly lost their power to enter the south of Korean Peninsula.
However, due to this incident, the Yamato Kingdom rapidly lost influence in the southern Korean Peninsula.
However, due to this incident, the Yamato Kingdom rapidly lost influence in the southern Korean Peninsula.

sen.j: またオホド王の登場以降、東北から南九州に及ぶ地域の統合が急速に進み、政治的な統一がなされたとする見解がある。
sen.e: Also, it is seen that the regions between Tohoku and the south Kyushu rapidly consolidated and political unification was seen after the time of King Ohodo.
Also, it can be seen that the regions between Tohoku and southern Kyushu rapidly consolidated and became politically unified after the time of King Ohodo.
Also, it can be seen that the regions between Tohoku and southern Kyushu rapidly consolidated and became politically unified after the time of King Ohodo.

sen.j: その後ヤマト王権は対外指向が弱まり、内向性が強くなった。
sen.e: After that, the Yamato sovereignty began showing less features of foreign orientation and more features of introversion.
After that, the Yamato Kingdom became less foreign-orientated and more inward-looking.
After that, the Yamato Kingdom became less foreign-orientated and more inward-looking.

sen.j: 朝鮮半島から暦法など中国の文物を移入するとともに豪族や民衆の系列化・組織化を漸次的に進めて内政面を強化していった。
sen.e: During that time, the Yamato sovereignty imported Chinese products of culture, such as rekiho (method of making calendars) from the Korean Peninsula, and at the same time, they enforced domestic administration.

At the same time the Yamato Kingdom was importing Chinese culture, such as calendar making, from the Korean Peninsula, it was strengthening domestic administration by gradually organizing both the ruling elite and the common people.

At the same time the Yamato Kingdom was importing Chinese culture, such as calendar making, from the Korean Peninsula, it was strengthening domestic administration by gradually organizing both the ruling elite and the common people.

sen.j: また、王族や有力豪族の間で紛争が多数発生するようにもなった。
sen.e: Conflicts between royal families and gozoku also occurred frequently.
Conflicts between the royals and the elite families also occurred frequently.
Conflicts between the royals and the elite families also occurred frequently.

sen.j: こうした中で6世紀末、幾つかの紛争に勝利した推古天皇、聖徳太子、蘇我馬子らは強固な政治基盤を築きあげ、冠位十二階や十七条憲法の制定など官僚制を柱とする王権の革新を積極的に進めた。
sen.e: At the end of the sixth century, Empress Suiko, Prince Shotoku, and SOGA no Umako, after winning in several conflicts, established firm political foundations and actively reformed the sovereignty based on the bureaucracy system such as Kan I junikai (twelve grades of cap rank) and Seventeen-Article Constitution.

At the end of the sixth century, Empress Suiko, Prince Shotoku, and SOGA no Umako, after emerging victorious from several conflicts, established firm political foundations and actively reformed the polity by basing it on bureaucratic systems such as Kan'i junikai (twelve cap rank system) and the Seventeen-Article Constitution.

At the end of the sixth century, Empress Suiko, Prince Shotoku, and SOGA no Umako, after emerging victorious from several conflicts, established firm political foundations and actively reformed the polity by basing it on bureaucratic systems such as Kan'i junikai (twelve cap rank system) and the Seventeen-Article Constitution.

sen.j: これによりヤマト王権という政治形態は解消され、古代ヤマト国家が形成されていくこととなる。
sen.e: With their political reformations, the political form of the Yamato sovereignty began to disappear; which was replaced by ancient Yamato state.
With these political reformations, the Yamato Kingdom's form of government began to disappear, becoming replaced by the ancient Yamato state.
With these political reformations, the Yamato Kingdom's form of government began to disappear, becoming replaced by the ancient Yamato state.

tit.e: Ogo (literally, a title of a king)

sen.j: ヤマト王権の王は中華王朝や朝鮮半島諸国など対外的には「倭国王」「倭王」と称し、国内向けには「治天下大王」「大王」「大公主」などと称していた。
sen.e: The kings of the Yamato sovereignty called themselves"Wakokuo" or"Wao" (the King of Wa) to foreign countries such as the Chinese Dynasties and countries in Korean Peninsula and "Amenoshitashiroshimesu," "okimi" (the title of the king of Wa),"okimi" (great king), or "the title of the king of Wa" within Japan.

The kings of the Yamato Kingdom called themselves "Wakokuo" or "Wao" (King of Wa) when dealing with foreign countries such as China or the Korean kingdoms, and "Ame-no-shita Shiroshimesu Okimi" (literally Great King of all that is under Heaven), "Okimi" (Great King) or "Okiminushi" (Great Lord) domestically.

The kings of the Yamato Kingdom called themselves "Wakokuo" or "Wao" (King of Wa) when dealing with foreign countries such as China or the Korean kingdoms, and "Ame-no-shita Shiroshimesu Okimi" (literally Great King of all that is under Heaven), "Okimi" (Great King) or "Okiminushi" (Great Lord) domestically.

sen.j: 考古学の成果から5世紀ごろから「治天下大王」（あめのしたしろしめすおおきみ）という国内向けの称号が成立したことが判明しているが、これはこの時期に倭国は中華王朝と異なる別の天下であるという意識が生まれていたことの表れだと評価されている。
sen.e: The title "Amenoshitashiroshimesu" known to have been established around the fifth century from archaeological studies is viewed as an evidence that suggests that they perceived Wakoku as a different tenka (the realm) from the Chinese dynasties.

The title "Ame-no-shita Shiroshimesu Okimi" known from archaeological studies to have been established around the fifth century is viewed as evidence of the perception that Wakoku was a different 'tenka' (realm, written with the same characters as 'Ame-no-shita') from the Chinese dynasties.

The title "Ame-no-shita Shiroshimesu Okimi" known from archaeological studies to have been established around the fifth century is viewed as evidence of the perception that Wakoku was a different 'tenka' (realm, written with the same characters as 'Ame-no-shita') from the Chinese dynasties.

sen.j: 元々ヤマトの範囲は奈良盆地東南部つまり天理市南部から桜井市北部の東辺の地であったと推測されている。
sen.e: It is estimated that Yamato ranged from the south east of Nara basin, the south of Tenri city, to the north east of Sakurai city.
It is believed that Yamato ranged from the south east of the Nara Basin, southern Tenri City, to the north east of Sakurai City.
It is believed that Yamato ranged from the south east of the Nara Basin, southern Tenri City, to the north east of Sakurai City.

sen.j: そこには三輪山山麓部の纏向遺跡には最古級の前方後円墳である箸墓古墳があり、また天理市の南部に所在する初期ヤマト政権の大王の墓を含むと推測されている大和古墳群がある。
sen.e: In these regions, Hashihaka tomb, the oldest keyhole-shaped mound, is found in Makimuku ruins at the foot of Mt. Miwa and Oyamato tomb group, where the king tombs of early Yamato sovereignty is thought to be located, is found in the south of Tenri city.

This area contains Hashihaka tomb, the oldest keyhole-shaped mound and part of the Makimuku ruins at the foot of Mt. Miwa and, to the south of Tenri city, the Oyamato tomb group, where the royal tombs of the early Yamato Kingdom are thought to be located.

This area contains Hashihaka tomb, the oldest keyhole-shaped mound and part of the Makimuku ruins at the foot of Mt. Miwa and, to the south of Tenri city, the Yamato tomb group, where the royal tombs of the early Yamato Kingdom are thought to be located.
sen.cmt: 大和古墳群のOyamatoをYamatoに修正しました。

sen.j: 平安時代初期に編集された『和名抄』に、大和国城下郡に大和郷（於保夜末止）が記されている。
sen.e: In"Wamyo-sho" (a dictionary compiled in the Heian period), edited in the early Heian period, describes Yamato mura (also called Ohoyamato) located in Yamashiro Shimogori of the Yamato Province.
"Wamyosho", a dictionary compiled in the early Heian period, describes Yamato-mura (also called Ohoyamato) located in Yamashiro Shimogori in Yamato Province.
"Wamyosho", a dictionary compiled in the early Heian period, describes Yamato-mura (also called Ohoyamato) located in Shikino-shimono-kori in Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: Yamashiro Shimogoriを Shikino-shimono-koriに修正しました。

sen.j: その地は大和神社の付近と推測でき、もとはその周辺をヤマトといったのに始まるのではないかと考える人も多い。
sen.e: Yamato mura is estimated to be the surrounding areas of the present day Oyamato-jinja Shrine and some view this area as the first one that came to be referred to as Yamato.
Yamato-mura is believed to be the area surrounding the present-day Oyamato-jinja Shrine and some view this area as the first one that came to be referred to as Yamato.
Yamato-mura is believed to be the area surrounding the present-day Oyamato-jinja Shrine and some view this area as the first one that came to be referred to as Yamato.

sen.j: その地域を根拠地として政権が成立したことから、その政治勢力をヤマト政権と呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: As this area was the base of the Yamato sovereignty, the political power arose from this area was named the Yamato sovereignty.
As this area was the base of the kingdom, the political power that arose from this area was named the Yamato Kingdom.
As this area was the base of the kingdom, the political power that arose from this area was named the Yamato Kingdom.

sen.j: なお、ヤマトは奈良盆地全体を指すこともあった。
sen.e: Yamato also referred to the whole area of Nara basin.
Yamato also referred to the whole of the Nara Basin.
Yamato also referred to the whole of the Nara Basin.

sen.j: その後、ヤマト王権の支配権が及ぶ範囲をヤマトと呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: Subsequently, the areas governed by the Yamato sovereignty also came to be called Yamato.
Subsequently, the areas governed by the Yamato Kingdom also came to be called Yamato.
Subsequently, the areas governed by the Yamato Kingdom also came to be called Yamato.

sen.j: （詳細は→大和）
sen.e: (For details => see Yamato)
(For details see Yamato)
(For details see Yamato)

sen.j: 7世紀末まで日本列島を代表する政権は九州にありヤマト王権は一地方政権に過ぎなかったとする説もあるが、埼玉県稲荷山古墳と熊本県江田船山古墳から「ワカタケル大王」と推定される銘の鉄剣が出土していること、様々な考古学的遺物などから成立する余地はないと考えられている。
sen.e: Some view that the central political regime of the Japanese Islands existed in Kyushu and that the Yamato sovereignty was only one local government; however, as iron sword estimated as that of King Wakatakeru was found from the Inariyama-kofun Tumulus and the Eta Funayama Tumulus, this theory is not thought to be valid.

There is an opinion that the main political regime of the Japanese Islands until the end of the seventh century existed in Kyushu and that the Yamato Kingdom was only one regional government, but since iron swords believed to be King Wakatakeru's were found in the Inariyama burial mound and the Eta Funayama burial mound, this theory is not thought to be valid.

There is an opinion that the main political regime of the Japanese Islands until the end of the seventh century existed in Kyushu and that the Yamato Kingdom was only one regional government, but since iron swords believed to be King Wakatakeru's were found in the Inariyama burial mound (Saitama prefecture) and the Eta Funayama burial mound (Kumamoto prefecture), this theory is not thought to be valid.
sen.cmt: the Inariyama burial mound に(Saitama prefecture)を加え、the Eta Funayama burial moundに (Kumamoto prefecture)を加えました。

sen.j: （→九州王朝説）
sen.e: (the theory of Kyushu dynasty)
(the Kyushu Dynasty theory)
(the Kyushu Dynasty theory)

sen.j: また、ヤマト王権をめぐって主として愛好家により日本神話や記紀編年の自由な解釈に基づく「謎解き」に類する説が多く主張されているが、そのほぼ全ては史料批判を満たしていないものであり学問的価値に乏しい。
sen.e: Also, based on their free interpretations of the Japanese myths and "Record of Ancient Matters" and "Chronicles of Japan," many theories have been claimed by the fanciers of the Yamato sovereignty to uncover mysteries of its historical facts; however, most of them do not fulfill the criticisms of the historical facts and are less likely to have academic values.

Also, many theories of the "mystery-solving" type, based on loose interpretations of Japanese mythology and the chronologies in the "Kojiki" (Record of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki", have been asserted by Yamato Kingdom enthusiasts, but these nearly always fail to satisfy historical scrutiny and are of limited academic value.

Also, many theories of the "mystery-solving" type, based on loose interpretations of Japanese mythology and the chronologies in the "Kojiki" (Record of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki", have been asserted by Yamato Kingdom enthusiasts, but these nearly always fail to satisfy historical scrutiny and are of limited academic value.
